events.target_title: Vala autocomplete do not work
64-bit memory access alignment issues leading to segfault on sparc64

push_data.commit_title: Replace pointer aliasing in unit test

events.target_title: Avoid potential 64-bit pointer aliasing alignment issues
Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
I'm sorry, I totally missed your merge request here, @psumbera . I submitted a new bug report for the same issue in #34 .
The Debian sparc64 build was running into the same issues as reported by you, and I simply patched it up by replacing the 64-bit memory access with memcpy's in !26 . This is a safe option for any platform and will not even incur a runtime cost on any platform where unaligned 64-bit memory access isn't a problem.

I didn't look into the actual reason why the allocated memory wasn't 64-bit aligned in the first place.
IMHO, it would make sense to assure proper memory alignment to avoid inefficient memory access, but I don't see how this can be done in a safe way with the current implementation. As I understand, the memory referenced by the attributes can be arbitrarily aligned due to packing. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

@dueno already merged !27 , but perhaps we can work out something that optimises memory management to avoid the memcpy call? Simply fixing the allocation will not be enough, as the compiler won't recognise the 'safe' pointers and will still generate a memcpy function call. I don't want to go back to pointer aliasing, as this may still pose a risk in the future if pointer semantics change on one platform.

events.target_title: Make gck attribute value allocation aligned for 64bit systems

note.body:
Possibly, but I'm not sure if this is going to help.
The link to the kernel docs I posted in the other issue ( https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/unaligned-memory-access.txt ) mentions the risk of having packed data structures where members aren't ordered by alignment. In the examples mentioned there however, the compiler will at least be able to figure our when it needs to access memory via an unaligned load/store - or add padding to the data strucutre.
This wasn't the case with gcr, because the serialised data structure is treated like an array of bytes.
Consider what happens when you put bools and ulongs side by side - if the serialisation packs them tightly, then unaligned fields are *always* a possibility.

Example:
```
R=refcount B=bool L=ulong
00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0a 0b 0c 0d 0e 0f 10 11 12
RRRRRRRRRRR BB RRRRRRRRRRR LLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL
```

I didn't look at how attributes are actually packed by gcr, but this is certainly something to consider.

note.body: @mschraal What's the reason for adding a bunch of `_METADATA_KEYS_*` to the `GrlTrackerWrapper` class instead of making them variables of the specific functions?

events.target_title: GrlTracker: optimize metadata key requests

note.body:
@jfelder Yes I understand that. My question was about this issue text seemingly asking to add separate lists like

*  `_METADATA_KEYS_ARTIST_CHANGE`
*  `_METADATA_KEYS_ALBUM_CHANGE`

to the class, when I think it would be cleaner to define them as local variables in their functions `_check_album_change()` and `_check_artist_change()`.

events.target_title: GrlTracker: optimize metadata key requests

note.body: @jfelder @mschraal Almost done with this. Had to do some reading to understand how grilo and its tracker plugins work, which was harder to figure out than anticipated because of missing documentation. Now I have some questions about the existing code. Looking for example at [this line](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-music/blob/master/gnomemusic/grilowrappers/grltrackerwrapper.py#L509), why doesn’t the keys list also contain `Grl.METADATA_KEY_ID`? After all, we have `SELECT ... AS $id` in the SPARQL query and [this comment](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/grilo-plugins/blob/master/src/tracker/grl-tracker-source-api.c#L731) gave me the impression that the `$id` represents `Grl.METADATA_KEY_ID`.

events.target_title: GrlTracker: optimize metadata key requests

note.body: Note that this isn’t the only instant, there are a lot more calls to `query` further down in the code where some of the keys are missing. I’m just gonna orient myself after the queries for now and make a merge request where we can discuss things further, if that is okay. I’m also going to try and add some comments that explain how this querying business works.

events.target_title: GrlTracker: optimize metadata key requests

note.body:
I just realized that putting in an empty list as the `keys` argument of `query` seems to work just as well! This is what you meant with your last comment @jfelder, right? But we should still use the proper keys because the plugin behavior might be changed in the future to the expected behavior of the returned media object only containing information about the specified keys?

I’ve also realized that some queries contain duplicate columns and in general a lot of improvements could be made to the code. Since I feel I finally have a really good understanding of this section of code, I’d like to do some refactoring (The code contains a couple FIXMEs asking for that). I’ll create a WIP merge request later today with the first couple changes, but I estimate this would be about a month in the working (not because it’s *such* a huge task, but because my time is limited haha).

events.target_title: gnome-shell.css: #panel's "border-radius" only takes first value
Brightness and contrast controls not working: HP Scanjet 5500c

note.body:
I have the same issue with my HP Laser 135a scanner.

The issue is also exists for other scanners:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/simple-scan/+bug/1327801

I investigate this issue, and it occurs when there is no `Sane.NAME_CONTRAST` option_descriptor:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/simple-scan/blob/master/src/scanner.vala#L1139

I investigated why Xsane is working, and it seems that xsane is modifing the output data:
1. First by creating Gamma correction function:
  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_correction#Microsoft_Windows,_Mac,_sRGB_and_TV/video_standard_gammas
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-gamma.c#L1322
2. Then applying it to every pixel/channel data:
  https://github.com/kkaempf/xsane/blob/master/src/xsane-scan.c#L250

This method is very efficient, and universal. It allows to enable brightness/contrast manipulation for every device.

@robert.ancell I would like to implement that feature. Do you think such patch could be accepted by simple-scan?

events.target_title: Scanning doesn't work with epson xp-440

note.body:
The issue is `source` descriptor. which is unable to set:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/simple-scan/blob/master/src/scanner.vala#L904

The descriptor is available but the `values` are wrong.
```
[+11.21s] DEBUG: scanner.vala:888: sane_get_option_descriptor (2)
[+11.21s] DEBUG: scanner.vala:738: Option 2: name='source' title='Document Source' type=string size=15 values=["Document Table"] cap=soft-detect
[+11.21s] DEBUG: scanner.vala:741:   Description: Document Source
```
Seems that it is an Epson driver issue.

events.target_title: Newsprint plugin: Add SPI and LPI parameter
GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
I have the same problem.

- Pop!_OS 19.10 x86_64
- mutter 3.34.1+git20191107-1ubuntu1~19.10.1pop0~1573683812~19.10~50e928a
- gnome-shell 3.34.1-1ubuntu1pop0~1573148724~19.10~f65f9b1

The `gnome-shell` run as the `gdm` user doesn't quit after I have logged in, and it keeps eating up more RAM. My laptop has an NVIDIA GeForce MX150 and Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2), and is capable of hybrid graphics. gnome-shell leaks memory in both hybrid graphics mode and Intel-only mode.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
Some people have suggested that buggy GNOME shell extensions may be to blame. So far I have disabled all of the non-default extensions, leaving the default ones that came with Pop!_OS running.

The gdm gnome-shell instance *still* won't quit automatically, and it still keeps eating up more RAM.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
@ITwrx There's the `gdm` *process* and then there's the `gdm` *user*.

On my laptop, when I'm logged into a GNOME desktop session, there are two `gnome-shell` processes running: one is run as me, the other is run as the `gdm` user. I'm talking about the `gnome-shell` instance that is run as the `gdm` user. That process is apparently responsible for the login screen, and that's the one that is leaking memory. According to some people on the internet, that `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance is really *not* supposed to keep running after a user has logged into a desktop session, though I cannot speak for the correctness of that claim.

events.target_title: GNOME Shell uses a lot of RAM after heavy use why ??

note.body:
My laptop has both Intel UHD Graphics (Whiskey Lake 3x8 GT2) and an NVIDIA GeForce MX150. And it is possible switch among three graphics modes (restart required):
- hybrid graphics
- intel-only graphics
- nvidia-only graphics

Here are some of the related, installed drivers and packages:

| package or driver | version |
| ------ | ------ |
| i965-va-driver | 2.3.0-0ubuntu2 |
| xserver-xorg-video-intel | 2:2.99.917+git20190815-1 |
| intel-media-va-driver:amd64 | 19.2.1+dfsg1-2ubuntu1 |
| nvidia-driver-440 [*] | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| nvidia-dkms-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |
| xserver-xorg-video-nvidia-440 | 440.31-1pop1~1573485407~19.10~af08493 |


I have done more testing and here are my discoveries so far:

If I enable nvidia-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP and SIGTERM by respawning, complete with the ibus-related child processes;
- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance would immediately use up about 180 MiB RAM right-off-the-bat, and the RAM usage would keep climbing;

If I enable intel-only graphics:

- The `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance responds to SIGHUP (but not SIGTERM) by respawning. The respawned `gnome-shell` instance will *not* have ibus-related child processes;
- The respawned `gdm`-user `gnome-shell` instance will start at about 39 MiB RAM usage, and pretty much stay there.

[*] The `nvidia-driver-440` metapackage pulls in *a lot* of real, nvidia-related packages, most of which have the exact same version number, so I'm not going to list them all one-by-one.

events.target_title: Borders of edited parts in PDF format
Snap to top and bottom (edges) too

note.body:
@fmuellner it's very true that the auto maximise using the top edge is a super-useful feature, and we shouldn't give it up. However it is also true that screens are becoming bigger and bigger, and it's not so uncommon to have to compare two documents. While code tends to be be compact on the X Axis, and therefore a left-right comparison is pretty handy, that's not the case for anything that is written text, for example written documents, where the X axis is pretty important.

Maybe, from an user-prospective point of view, a proposal could be to have a combination of top edge and press of a shortcut:
- only top edge --> maximise
- top edge + Super --> split half top 

The bottom edge is not used at the moment, IIRC, so that can actually be used as the hint to have the half split.

Regarding shortcut, a proposal would be to have Super + Top Arrow and Super + Right Arrow, to have consistency with the other two.

My two cents.

events.target_title: gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
gtk_window_set_resizable() doesn't works
Allow layer boundaries to be adjusted automatically

note.body:
I and many other people I know switched from GIMP to Photoshop as soon as they could afford it primarily because this issue is too disruptive to workflow (brush options were the other factor but that has mostly been resolved). It seems like many people don't post about this because they assume that such an important feature can't be that far away, but this issue was reported 17 years ago and is still not a feature. This is why after 16 years of trying GIMP roughly once a year, I am speaking up. I can't stress enough the importance of this feature so please, if anyone reading this has any influence on development priorities, please make this feature a higher priority. In my opinion it by far the most important thing on the roadmap. 

For cases where specific layer sizes are desirable my suggestion is to have a "Lock layer size" checkbox (in the layer properties dialogue) that disables dynamic resizing an enables the layer dimension inputs. The default behaviour for new layers could be a document or program setting, which may be useful for animation projects.

events.target_title: Can't delete TIF files that Gimp 2.10.12 has exported.

note.body:
I have encountered this issue as well.

Gimp 2.10.14 from gimp.org
Windows 10 64-bit

I have tried the following to delete/alter the files (after both a restart and a cold reboot):
* Normal delete (to recycle bin)
* Force delete
* Normal delete in safe mode
* Force delete in safe mode
* Rename in normal and safe mode
* Rename the parent directory in normal and safe mode

All these attempts failed silently. Rename attempts cause File Explorer to hang.

Reopening the file in Gimp works fine.
Attempting to use the file in Scribus 1.4.8 shows an image with many layers missing (which may be a Scribus issue).
Using IrfanView 4.37 to view the file shows a black image (maybe it doesn't support multilayer tiffs).

I've used Microsoft's Process Explorer to check for hanging file locks. There are none, although the files very much act like they are locked.

I've turned off thumbnail generation in Windows and deleted all thumbs.db files using the Windows Drive Cleanup tool. No dice.

note.body:
In this issue: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/3747#

I've uploaded an xcf and associated layered tiff. Exporting the xcf as a multilayer tiff has caused this behavior 100% of the time.

Warning: Downloading the tiff to W10 will leave you a stuck file as described in this issue (and the other).

events.target_title: Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body:
My solution to (finally) removing these files (assumes knowledge of basic command line usage):

1. Open a command prompt as an administrator.
1. Use ctrl+alt+del to access the task manager.
1. On the processes tab (with show more details selected). Find and terminate the Windows Explorer task (right-click/end task), which will cause any open explorer windows and your taskbar to disappear.
1. Use the command prompt to delete affected files.
1. Use the command **start explorer.exe** to restart windows explorer.

After you're done, it may be worth rebooting just to be sure everything returns to normal operations. Hope this helps someone.

events.target_title: window titlebar buttons placed left causes flickering text and non responsive buttons

note.body:
It seems to be caused by https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-tweaks/commit/6ecb055b1c2cf75f517ee8a81fc57d9fbb487637
I have tried fixing it myself but without much success.

I can somewhat workaround it with:
```
diff --git a/gtweak/tweakview.py b/gtweak/tweakview.py
index 5de11d6..515d0f1 100644
--- a/gtweak/tweakview.py
+++ b/gtweak/tweakview.py
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
         Gtk.ApplicationWindow.__init__(self,
                                        application=app,
                                        show_menubar=False)
-        self.set_size_request(-1, 700)
+        self.set_size_request(950, 700)
         self.set_position(Gtk.WindowPosition.CENTER)
         self.set_icon_name("org.gnome.tweaks")
 
@@ -168,7 +168,6 @@ class Window(Gtk.ApplicationWindow):
 
     def main_content(self):
         right_box = Gtk.Box(orientation=Gtk.Orientation.VERTICAL)
-        right_box.set_size_request(750, -1)
 
         self.stack = Gtk.Stack()
         self.stack.get_style_context().add_class("main-container")

```
but that defeats the purpose of the change linked above as we won't be able to go below 950x700 anymore, it also exposes yet another regression introduced by the change — switching buttons from left -> right leaves an empty space until the window is redrawn? (eg. resized).

note.body:

instructions. The first run of 'make clean' in the ~/libinsane directory
showed a lot of errors so I ran again as sudo. This seemed to do a much
better job! I then ran make install PREFIX=/usr as normal user and the
build seemed to be good. However, trying to run Paperwork again gives the
same errors as before. I tried logging out and back in, and also restarting
OS (power recycle) when that didn't work. That didn't work, either, so I
actually removed the entire libinsane directory (make clean was informing
me that directories under libinsane could not be removed) - see below:

I then followed *ALL* the instructions under 'Compilation' in
https://doc.openpaper.work/libinsane/latest/libinsane/install.html (which I
see you have corrected) - and I'm still getting exactly the same failure!!

```
mike@HP6730b:~/libinsane$ paperwork
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line

    raise ValueError('Namespace %s not available' % namespace)
```

events.target_title: Enable clicking to unlock screen

note.body:
Users have problems accessing a locked session. Pulling the wallpaper shield upwards by mouse is not an obvious action.

Also, the wallpaper shield cannot quite often be deactivated by "any key" (it simply stays in foreground and it can be moved away only with mouse action), so the user stays logged out without any clue how to proceed - other than hard reset of the computer.

events.target_title: Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis
Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis

note.body:
The extension doesn't provide the functionality in question, I just used it as an idea for design. Sorry for the misunderstanding. 

But even if an extension provided the functionality, extensions are not officially supported and the API is not stable. Relying on a third party, that isn't guaranteed to work between versions, for providing basic functionality is bad design in my opinion.

I'm not saying that extensions should be incorporated into shell as they have their use: customization (e.g. Dash to Dock/Panel) or special configurations (themes, distros such ZorinOS that make gnome more Windows-like) are valid reasons to use extensions. However, using two audio sources concurrently doesn't seem to me like something _that_ special. That's why other DEs provide the functionality built-in through an applet or in settings (I have first-hand experience with Plasma and Windows, can't say for others)

EDIT: grammar

events.target_title: Add way to change audio output (speakers vs headphones) on a per application basis

note.body: You're right, this may not so basic as it seems to me. Also this feature may be better suited for gnome-control-center as opposed to gnome-shell. Should I open the same issue there and close this one?

events.target_title: Windows 10 crash install on host AMD Ryzen 7

note.body:
Same problem on a Ryzen 5 1500. I tested windows 10 1909 and 1803 and both BSOD with `SYSTEM THREAD EXCEPTION NOT HANDLED`. Windows 7 and any other OS, however, don't crash.

What is even more interesting is that the same error is present on my laptop (Ryzen 2500U), however there
everything runs fine.

events.target_title: Required feature, Quick Access Bar
Required feature, Quick Access Bar

note.body:
From my point of view it would gain speed, mainly for people who arrive new to gimp and don't know their keyboard shortcuts

The keyboard shortcuts are fine but when you use different programs to edit an image at the end you get confused between so many keyboard shortcuts

Thanks!

events.target_title: Required feature, Quick Access Bar

note.body:
I think it is easier to associate numbers and colors to actions than key combinations

I think the quick access bar would be very useful, but like any new feature until it is tested the improvement cannot be measured

Thanks

events.target_title: Required feature, Quick Access Bar

note.body:
Well, the truth is that I don't know any research that supports my theory

But I think it would be great to have next to the mouse pointer .., for example:
the last two brushes used, the last 4 colors used, my 8 favorite tool presets and my most used commands, especially when you don't have the keyboard especially comfortable

And if when you put the mouse pointer over the quick access bar, it shows you the corresponding keyboard shortcut, it would even serve to quickly learn the keyboard shortcuts

Anyway ... it was just an idea

events.target_title: gnome-session should not save/restore RequiredComponents (causes upgrade failure when switching to systemd startup)

note.body:
>  It turns out that users can still enable session auto-saving

Isn't implementing the XSM Protocol a core task of gnome-session?

[man page gnome-session(1)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-session/blob/master/doc/man/gnome-session.1#L29) here in the repository says so:
`\fIgnome-session\fP is an X11R6 session manager. It can manage GNOME applications as well as any X11R6 SM compliant application.`


The first link in the "Links" section on [https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement) is to [More Than You Ever Wanted To Know About XSMP](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/SessionManagement/NotesOnXSMP) on Gnome wiki by Dan Winship.

The X11R7.7 XSM Protocol specification [https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.7/doc/libSM/xsmp.html] is not tied to an X server:
>  There was much discussion over whether the XSMP protocol should use X as the transport protocol or whether it should use its own independent transport. It was decided that it would use an independent protocol for several reasons. First, the Session Manager should be able to manage programs that do not maintain an X connection.

The functionality provided by XSM remains useful under wayland and systemd.
 
2 days ago on a laptop I was installing Debian sid on, I wanted to disable some autostart services (the a11y background services), and noticed the news announced here: https://blogs.gnome.org/benzea/2019/10/01/gnome-3-34-is-now-managed-using-systemd/ .
I failed to find a design document driving this ongoing effort. Looking for that I found this issue, and I now am doubting there is any such a document, I am afraid there is no clear direction.

Specifically, I discovered the new `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` entry in the .desktop files in `/etc/xdg/autostart`. I found it in the comment in the blog post. I also noticed that similar functionality is provided in the .service files for D-Bus activation (eg: /usr/share/dbus-1/services/org/a11y.Bus.service), by the `SystemdService=` key (Documentation: search "SystemdService" in https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-daemon.1.html and https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html ).
  Then I reviewed the [freedesktop.org Desktop Application Autostart Specification]( https://specifications.freedesktop.org/autostart-spec/0.5/index.html) and wondered what is the difference between a spec compliant `NotShowIn=GNOME` and a custom `X-GNOME-HiddenUnderSystemd=true` (apart from compatibility with downgrading of gnome-session package).
The I came to this issue to write this comment.

Without any intention to be abrasive, these above are my doubts. They are summarized by: is the session save and restore functionality going down the drain without alternatives?

Now my 2 cents. 
I wonder if implementing a systemd generator to convert the .desktop files in /etc/xdg/autostart would be any better:
*  it could easily handle the .desktop files from ~/.config/gnome-session/saved-session/  both the obsolete ones this issue is about AND the good ones from a good previous saved session.
* With a generator, only the management of the processes would be handed over to systemd in the form of unit files,
* while the management of the session in the XSM meaning would stay untouched, implemented by the .desktop files.
* The applicable existing specifications (XSM, XDG Autostart) would stay relevant and would guide the development.

Regards,

Marco Gamberoni

events.target_title: gedit plugin 'Find in Files' causes segfault

note.body:
I tried building gedit and gedit-plugins from git master and still had the problem. However, I didn't manage to reproduce the problem from a live distro. The same actions only produced the warning
``` 
(gedit:2378): Gtk-WARNING **: 16:41:57.215: Unable to parse accelerator '\u0002': ignored request to install 4 accelerators
```

Perhaps it is something specific to my system. 

Many thanks for having had a look at it.
